body: Also really want to say "thanks" to all Alacritty developers for making & improving Alacritty. It's one of the best cross-platform terminals that I've used.
What is the error saying? Is it actually crashed, then there should be a backtrace available. Or is it just frozen?
The terminal just freezes, with the output stuck. Then I tried to click the ‘X’ to close the window, the crash on the screenshot happened
Sometimes it stuck at 12%, sometimes stuck at 20%. Seems totally random. But never seen it make it to 100%.
Can you check where it is stuck at please?

Initial debugging shows that "PTY reader" thread stuck at here `GetQueuedCompletionStatusEx`, which seems to be waiting indefinitely: 

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/4710575/123374865-65979b80-d5ba-11eb-9ffb-97052daed6ac.png)

Full stack:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/4710575/123374959-852ec400-d5ba-11eb-9502-d2652f3aef22.png)

issue.title: Slow SGR parsing performance under heavy load
issue.body:
### System

OS: Windows 10
Version:  0.8.0

### Description

This is a sister issue of #5266.

By using this benchmark software https://github.com/cmuratori/termbench/releases/tag/V1, on Linux I found that  rendering non-colored text is about 70x faster than rendering colored-text (release build, version 0.8.0 from PopOS repo)

Note that the benchmark currently can't run fully on Windows because of #5266. Still I am able to use VS to gather the performance trace of alacritty and this is what I got:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/4710575/123376719-89a8ac00-d5bd-11eb-997f-9ff7ed75877e.png)

This shows that the CPU usage of VT parsing is a little higher than expected.

Note that this trace is gathered using Debug build, because with Release build some of the stack is not available. Based on my result on Linux mentioned above, I think it's safe to say that VT parsing still drags the rendering behind when the load is heavy.

body: The location where Alacritty is stuck would be much more useful than the location of its depedencies. Seems to be somewhere in the Windows tty module? Sounds like it is a ConPTY thing.
Yeah I think it might be ConPTY thing. Will try to dig later.

issue.title: Fix potential deadlock regarding buffer condvar

repository.name: mio-anonymous-pipes
repository.description: mio::Evented wrapper for windows anonymous pipes

body: Hi @chrisduerr  turns out it's a bug in `mio-anonymouse-pipes`. The PR I linked fixed this issue. Thanks for the patient guidance :)
That's somewhat surprising, thanks for looking into it.

The fact that Windows Terminal works fine somewhat rules out ConPTY's fault. However even with the fix, the performance on Windows is still not good, because of ConPTY slowness. But that's another issue.

@chrisduerr do you happen to know the author of `mio-anonymouse-pipes` @davidhewitt ? So that we can merge this change soon? I can also repro this bug with vtebench (running in WSL), so I think it's actually more common that I thought.

> The fact that Windows Terminal works fine somewhat rules out ConPTY's fault.

The ConPTY version used by Windows Terminal is **significantly** different from Alacritty's version.

> @chrisduerr do you happen to know the author of mio-anonymouse-pipes @davidhewitt ?

I don't actually have much hope, but I'd like to give the PR a chance at least. Worst case the crate can be easily forked and we can move it to the Alacritty organization. IIRC there's also been the suggestion to replace this crate and iirc there should even be a code comment in the windows pty somewhere, but that would require someone who's actually interested in working on Windows.

> The ConPTY version used by Windows Terminal is significantly different from Alacritty's version.

Yea, it is. But the newer version of ConPTY bundled in Windows Terminal isn't really too fast, either 😅 . 

I am a casual contributor of the Windows Terminal project so I know a bit in this specific area. If there's anything I can help regarding ConPTY & related., I will see what I can do within my power.
